SP.P: There is not a moment to be lost in words; —this disguise I tore from the dead body of a Friar, as I pass'd our field of battle—it has gain'd me entrance to thy dungeon—now take it thou, and fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And Rolla—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Will remain here in thy place.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And die for me!—No!—Rather eternal tortures rack me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I shall not die, Alonzo.—It is thy life Pi∣zarro seeks, not Rolla's—and from my prison soon will thy arm deliver me;—or, should it be other∣wise—I am as a blighted plantain standing alone amid the sandy desert—Nothing seeks or lives be∣neath my shelter—Thou art a husband, and a fa∣ther—The being of a lovely wife and helpless in∣fant hang upon thy life—Go!—Go!—Alonzo!—Go—to save—not thyself—but Cora, and thy child!—

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Urge me not thus, my friend—I had pre∣par'd to die in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: To die in peace!—devoting her you've sworn to live for,—to madness, misery, and death! —For, be assured—the state I left her in forbids all hope, but from thy quick return.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Oh! God!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P:
If thou art yet irresolute, Alonzo—now heed me well.—I think thou hast not known that Rolla ever pledg'd his word, and shrunk from its fulfilment.—And, by the heart of truth I swear, if thou art proudly obstinate to deny thy friend the transport of preserving Cora's life, in thee,—no power that sways the will of man shall stir me hence—and thou'lt but have the desperate tri∣umph, of seeing Rolla perish by thy side,—with
the assur'd conviction, that Cora, and thy child, are lost for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Oh! Rolla!—you distract me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: A moment's further pause, and all is lost—The dawn approaches—Fear not for me—I will treat with Pizarro as for surrender and submission; —I shall gain time, doubt not—while thou, with a chosen band, passing the secret way, may'st at night return—release thy friend, and bear him back in triumph—Yes—hasten—dear Alonzo!—Even now I hear the frantic Cora call thee!—Haste!—Haste!—Haste!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Rolla, I fear your friendship drives me from honour, and from right.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Did Rolla ever counsel dishonour to his friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Oh! my preserver!—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I feel thy warm tears dropping on my cheek—Go!—I am rewarded—(Throws the Friar's garment over Alonzo.)—There! conceal thy face; and that they may not clank, hold fast thy chains—Now—God be with thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: At night we meet again.—Then,—so aid me Heaven! I return to save—or—perish with thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: He has pass'd the outer porch—He is safe!—He will soon embrace his wife and child! —Now, Cora, did'st thou not wrong me? This is the first time throughout my life I ever deceived men—Forgive me, God of truth! if I am wrong—Aonzo flatters himself that we shall meet again—Yes—There! (lifting his hands to heaven) assuredly, we shall meet again:—there possess in peace, the joys of everlasting love, and friendship—on earth, imperfect, and embitter'd—I will retire, lest the guard return before Alonzo may have pass'd their lines.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: No—not Pizarro's brutal taunts—not the glowing admiration which I feel for this noble youth, shall raise an interest in this harass'd bosom which honour would not sanction. If he reject the vengeance my heart has sworn against the ty∣rant, who's death alone can save this land—yet, shall the delight be mine to restore him to his Co∣ra's arms, to his dear child, and to the unoffend∣ing people, whom his virtues guide, and valour guards.—Alonzo, come forth!
Ha!—who art thou?—Where is Alonzo?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Alonzo's fled.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Fled!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Yes—and he must not be pursued—Par∣don this roughness, (seizing her hand)—but a mo∣ment's precious to Alonzo's flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: What if I call the guard?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Do so—Alonzo still gains time.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: What if thus I free myself?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Strike it to my heart—Still, with the con∣vulsive grasp of death, I'll hold thee fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Release me—I give my faith, I neither will alarm the guard, nor cause pursuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: At once, I trust thy word—A feeling bold∣ness in those eyes assures me that thy soul is noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: What is thy name? Speak freely—By my order the guard is remov'd beyond the outer porch.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: My name is Rolla.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: The Peruvian Leader?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I was so yesterday—to-day, the Spaniard's captive.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: And friendship for Alonzo, moved thee to this act?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Alonzo is my friend—I am prepared to die for him. Yet is the cause a motive stronger far than friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: One only passion else could urge such ge∣nerous rashness.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: And that is—

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Love?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: True!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Gallant!—ingenious Rolla!—Know that my purpose here was thine; and were I to save thy friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: How!—a woman bless'd with gentleness and courage, and yet not Cora!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Does Rolla think so meanly of all female hearts?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Not so—you are worse and better than we are!—

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: To save thee, Rolla, from the tyrant's vengeance—restore thee to thy native land—and thy native land to peace—would'st thou not rank Elvira with the good?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: To judge the action, I must know the means.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Take this dagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: How to be used?

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: I will conduct thee to the tent where fell Pizarro sleeps—The scourge of innocence—the terror of thy race—the fiend, that desolates thy afflicted country.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Have you not been injur'd by Pizarro?

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Deeply as scorn and insult can infuse their deadly venom.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: And you ask that I shall murder him in his sleep!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Would not he have murder'd Alonzo in his chains? He that sleeps, and he that's bound, are equally defenceless. Hear me, Rolla—so may I prosper in this perilous act as searching my full heart, I have put by all rancorous motive of pri∣vate vengeance there, and feel that I advance to my dread purpose in the cause of human nature, and at the call of sacred justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: The God of justice sanctifies no evil as a step towards good. Great actions cannot be achieved by wicked means.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Then, Peruvian! since thou do'st feel so coldly for thy country's wrongs, this hand, tho' it revolt my soul, shall strike the blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Then is thy destruction certain, and for Peru thou perishest!—Give me the dagger!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Now follow me;—but first—and dreadful is the hard necessity—you must strike down the guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: The soldier who was on duty here?

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Yes, him—else, seeing thee, the alarm will be instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: And I must stab that soldier as I pass?—Take back thy dagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Rolla!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: That soldier, mark me, is a man.—All are not men that bear the human form. He re∣fus'd my prayers—refus'd my gold—denying to admit me—till his own feelings brib'd him.—For my nation's safety, I would not harm that man!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Then he must be with us—I will answer for his safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Be that plainly understood between us:—for, whate'er betide our enterprize, I will not risk a hair of that man's head, to save my heartstrings from consuming fire.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: The inside of Pizarro's Tent.—Pizarro on a Couch, in disturbed sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: No mercy, traitor.—Now at his heart!—Stand off there, you—Let me see him bleed!—Ha! ha! ha!—Let me hear that groan again.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Tere!—Now, lose not a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: You must leave me now.—This scene of blood fits not a woman's presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: But a moment's pause may—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Go!—Retire to your own tent—and return not here—I will come to you.—Be thou not known in this business, I implore you!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: I will withdraw the guard that waits.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Now have I in my power the accurs'd de∣stroyer of my country's peace: yet tranquilly he rests.—God!—can this man sleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Away! away!—Hideous fiends!—Tear not my bosom thus!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P:
No: I was in error—the balm of sweet repose he never more can know.—Look here, am∣bition's fools!—Ye, by whose inhuman pride, the bleeding sacrifice of nations is held as nothing—behold the rest of the guilty!—He is at my mercy —and one blow!—No!—my heart and hand re∣fuse the act: Rolla cannot be an assassin!—Yet
Elvira must be saved! (Approaches the Couch.) Piz∣zaro! awake!—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Who?—Guard!—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Speak not—another word is thy death—Call not for aid—this arm will be swifter than thy guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Who art thou? and what is thy will?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I am thine enemy! Peruvian Rolla!—Thy death is not my will, or I could have slain thee sleeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Speak, what else?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Now thou art at my mercy—answer me I Did a Peruvian ever yet wrong or injure thee, or any of thy nation? Didst thou, or any of thy nation, ever yet shew mercy to a Peruvian in your power? Now shalt thou feel—and if thou hast a heart, thou'lt feel it keenly!—a Peruvian's venge∣ance! (Drops the dagger at his feet) There!

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Is it possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Can Pizarro be surprized at this? I thought Forgiveness of Injuries had been the Christian's precept—Thou seest, at least, it is the Peruvian's practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Rolla—thou hast indeed surpris'd—subdued me.
SP.STAGE: (Walks again aside as in irresolute thought.)

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Is it done? Is he dead? (Sees Pizarro) How!—still living! Then I am lost! And for you, wretched Peruvians! mercy is no more!—Oh! Rolla! treacherous or cowardly?—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: How can it be, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Away! Elvira speaks she knows not what! Leave me, (to Elvira) I conjure you, with Pizarro.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P:
How!—Rolla, do'st thou think I shall re∣tract
—or that I meanly will deny, that in thy hand I plac'd a poignard to be plung'd into that tyrant's heart? No:—my sole regret is, that I trusted to thy weakness, and did not strike the blow myself. Too soon thou'lt learn that mercy to that man is direct cruelty to all thy race!

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Guard! quick! a guard to seize this fran∣tic woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Yes, a guard! I call them too! And soon I know they'll lead me to my death. But think not, Pizarro, the fury of thy flashing eyes shall awe me for a moment!—Nor think that woman's anger, or the feelings of an injured heart, prompted me to this design—No! Had I been only influ∣enced so—thus failing, shame and remorse would weigh me down. But though defeated and destroyed, as now I am, such is the greatness and the cause that urged me, I shall perish, glorying in the attempt, and my last breath of life shall speak the proud avowal of my purpose—to have rescued millions of innocents from the blood∣thirsty tyranny of ONE—by ridding the insulted world of THEE.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Had the act been noble as the motive—Rolla would not have shrunk from its perform∣ance.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Seize this discovered fiend, who sought to kill your Leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P:
Touch me not, at the peril of your souls; —I am your prisoner, and will follow you. But thou, their triumphant Leader, shall hear me. Yet, first—for thee, Rolla, accept my forgiveness: even had I been the victim of thy nobleness of heart, I should have admired thee for it—But 'twas myself
provok'd my doom—Thou would'st have shielded me.—Let not thy contempt follow me to the grave. Didst thou but know the spell-like arts, by which this hypocrite first undermined the virtue of a guileless heart! how, even in the pious sanctuary wherein I dwelt, by corruption and by fraud, he practis'd upon those in whom I most confided—'till my distempered fancy'led me, step by step, into the abyss of guilt—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Why am I not obeyed?—Tear her hence!

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: 'Tis past—but didst thou know my story, Rolla, thou would'st pity me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: From my soul I do pity thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Villains! drag her to the dungeon!—prepare the torture instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P:
Soldiers—but a moment more—'Tis to applaud your General—It is to tell the astonished world, that, for once, Pizarro's sentence is an act of justice. Yes, rack me with the sharpest tortures that ever agoniz'd the human frame; it will be justice. Yes—bid the minions of thy fury—wrench forth the sinews of those arms that have caress'd, and—even have defended thee! Bid them pour burning metal into the bleeding cases of those eyes, that so oft—oh God!—have hung with love and homage on thy looks—then approach me, bound on the abhorred wheel—there glut thy savage eyes with the convulsive spasms of what dishonoured bosom, which was once thy pillow!—Yet, will I bear it all; for it will be justice, all! And when thou shalt bid them tear me to my death, hoping that thy un∣shrinking ears may at last be feasted with the music of my cries, I will not utter one shriek or groan—but. to the last gasp, my body's patience
shall deride thy vengeance, as my soul defies thy power.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Hear'st thou the wretch whose hands were even now prepared for murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Yes! And if her accusation's false, thou wilt not shrink from hearing her if true, thy bar∣barity cannot make her suffer the pangs thy con∣science will inflict on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: And now, farewell, world!—Rolla, fare∣well! —Farewell! thou condemued of Heaven! (to Pizarro;)—for repentance and remorse, I know, will never touch thy heart. We shall meet again. Ha! be it thy horror here, to know that we shall meet hereafter! And when thy parting hour approaches—hark to the knell, whose dread∣ful beat will strike to thy despairing soul. Then, will vibrate on thy ear the curses of the cloister'd saint from whom you stole me. Then, the last shrieks which burst from my mother's breaking heart, as she died, appealing to her God against the seducer of her child! Then the blood-stifled groan of my murdered brother—murdered by thee, fell monster!—seeking atonement for his sister's ruin'd honour. I hear them now! To me the recollec∣tion's madness!—At such an hour,—what will it be to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: A moment's more delay, and at the peril of your lives—

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: I have spoken—and the last mortal frailty of my heart is past—And now, with an undaunted spirit, and unshaken firmness, I go to meet my destiny. That I could not live nobly, has been PIZARRO'S ACT. That I will die nobly, shall be my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P:
Rolla, I would not thou, a warrior,
valiant and renowned, should'st credit the vile tales of this frantic woman. The cause of all this fury—O! a wanton passion for the rebel youth Alonzo, now my prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Alonzo is not now thy prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I came to rescue him—to deceive his guard—I have succeeded;—I remain thy pri∣soner.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Alonzo fled?—Is then the vengeance dear∣est to my heart never to be gratified?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Dismiss such passions from thy heart; then thou'lt consult its peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: I can face all enemies that dare confront me —I cannot war against my nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Then, Pizarro, ask not to be deemed a hero—To triumph o'er ourselves is the only con∣quest, where fortune makes no claim. In battle, chance may snatch the laurel from thee, or chance may place it on thy brow—but in a contest with yourself, be resolute, and the virtuous impulse must be the victor.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Peruvian! thou shalt not find me to thee un∣grateful, or ungenerous—Return to your country∣men —You are at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Thou do'st act in this, as honour, and as du∣ty, bid thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: I cannot but admire, thee, Rolla, I wou'd we might be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Farewell. Pity Elvira! Become the friend of virtue—and thou wilt be mine

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P:
Ambition! tell me what is the phantom I have followed? where is the one delight which it has made my own? My fame is the mark of envy—my love the dupe of treachery—my glory
eclips'd by the boy I taught—my revenge de∣feated and rebuked by the rude honour of a savage oe—before whose native dignity of soul I have sunk confounded and subdued! I would I cou'd retrace my steps—I cannot—Would I could evade my own reflections!—No!—thought and memory are my Hell.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A thick Forest—In the back ground, a Hut almost covered by Boughs of Trees—A dreadful Storm, with Thunder and Lightning.—CORA has covered her Child on a bed of Leaves and Moss—her whole appearance is wild and distracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: O NATURE! thou hast not the strength of love. My anxious spirit is untired in its march; my wearied shivering frame sinks under it. And, for thee, my boy—when faint beneath thy lovely burden, could I refuse to give thy slumbers that poor bed of rest! O my child! were I assured thy father breathes no more, how quikly would I lay me down by thy dear side—but down—down for ever. (Thunder and Lightning.) I ask thee not, unpiying storm! to abate thy rage, in mercy to poor Cora's misery; nor while thy thunders spares his slumbers will I disturb my sleeping cherub. Though Heaven knows I wish to hear the voice of life, and feel that life is near me. But I will endure all while what I have of reason holds.

DIV4.HEAD: SONG.
DIV4.L: Yes, yes, be merciless, thou Tempest dire;
Unaw'd, unsheltered, I thy fury brave,
I'll bare my bosom to thy forked fire,
Let it but guide me to ALONZO'S grave!
O'er his pale corse then while thy lightnings glare,
I'll press thy clay-cold lips, and perish there:
But thou wilt wake again, my boy,
Again thou'lt rise to life and joy,
Thy father never!
Thy laghing eyes will meet the light,
Unconscious that eternal night
Veils his for ever.
On yon green bed of moss there lies my child,
Oh! safer lies from these chill'd arms apart;
He sleeps, sweet lamb! nor heeds the tempest wild,
Oh! sweeter sleeps, than near this breaking heart.
Alas! my babe, if thou would'st peaceful rest,
Thy cradle must not be thy mother's breast.
Yet, thou wilt wake again, my boy,
Again thou'lt rise to life and joy,
Thy father never!—
Thy laughing eyes will meet the light,
Unconscious that eternal night
Veils his for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Still, still, implacable! unfeeling elements! yet still dost thou sleep, my smiling innocent! O, death! when wilt thou grant to this babe's mother such repose? Sure I may shield thee better from the storm; my veil may—

DIV4.STAGE: While she is wrapping her mantle and her veil over him, Alonzo's voice is heard as a great▪ distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Cora!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Hah!!!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Cora!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora,
SP.P: O, my heart! Sweet Heaven deceive me not! Is it not Alonzo's voice?

SP.SPEAKER: Al
SP.P: Cora!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: It is—it is Alonzo!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Cora! my beloved!—

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Alonzo! Here! here! Alonzo!

SP.SPEAKER: 1 st Sol.
SP.P: I tell you we are near our out-posts, and the word we heard just now was the countersign.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Sol.
SP.P: Well, in our escape from the enemy, to have discover'd their secret passage thro' the rocks, will prove a lucky chance to us—Pizarro will re∣ward us.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 st Sol
SP.P: This way—The sun, though clouded, is on our left. (Perceives the child.) What have we here?—A child!—as I'm a soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Sol.
SP.P: 'Tis a sweet little babe. Now would it be a great charity to take this infant from its pagan mother's power.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 st Sol.
SP.P: It would so—I have one at home shall play with it.—Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora
SP.P: This way, dear Alon∣zo. Now am I right—there—there—under that tree. Was it possible the instinct of a mother's heart could mistake the spot! Now will you look at him as he sleeps, or shall I bring him waking with his full blue laughing eyes to welcome you at once—Yes—yes.—Stand thou there—I'll snatch him from his rosy slumber, blushing like the per∣sum'd morn

DIV4.STAGE: She runs up to the spot, and, finding only the mantle and veil, which she tears from the ground, and the child gone, (shrieks) and stands in speechless agony.

SP.SPEAKER: Al
SP.P: Cora!—my heart's be∣loved!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: He is gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Eternal God!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: He is gone!—my child! my child!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Where did you leave him?
Cora (dashing herself on the spot). Here!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P:
Be calm, beloved Cora—he has wak'd, and
crept to a little distance—we shall find him—Are you assured this was the spot you left him in?

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Did not these hands make that bed, and shelter for him? and is not this the veil that co∣vered him?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Here is a hut yet unobserved.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Ha! yes, yes! there lives the savage that has rob'd me of my child—(Beats at the door, ex∣claiming) Give me back my child—restore to me my boy!

DIV4.STAGE: Enter LAS CASAS from the Hut.

SP.SPEAKER: Las. C.
SP.P: Who calls me from my wretched soli∣tude?

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Give me back my child! (Goes into the hut, and calls) Fernando!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Almighty powers! do my eyes deceive me! Las Casas!

SP.SPEAKER: Las C.
SP.P: Alonzo,—my belov'd young friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: My rever'd instructor.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora
SP.P: Will you embrace this man before he restores my boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Alas, my friend—in what a moment of mi∣sery do we meet!

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Yet his look is goodness and humanity.—Good old man, have compassion on a wretched mother—and I will be your servant while I live.—But do not, for pity's sake—do not say, you have him not—do not say, you have not seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Las C.
SP.P: What can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: She is my wife, just rescued from the Spa∣niards' prison.—I learn'd she had fled to this wild forest—Hearing my voice, she left the child, and flew to meet me—he was left sleeping under yon∣der tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Las C.
SP.P: How! did you leave him?—Cora re∣turns).

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: O, you are right!—right!—unnatural mother, that I was—I left my child—I forsook my innocent—but I will fly to the earth's brink, but I will find him.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Forgive me, Las Casas, I must follow her? for at night, I must attempt brave Rolla's rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: Las C.
SP.P: I will not leave thee, Alonzo—you must try to lead her to the right—that way lies your camp—Wait not my infirm steps,—I follow thee, my friend.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: The Out-Post of the Spanish Camp.—The back ground wild and rocky, with a Torrent falling down the Precipice, over which a Bridge is formed. A fell'd Tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Almagro
SP.P: Bear him along—his story must be false.

DIV3.STAGE: ROLLA (in chains) brought in by Soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: False!—Rolla, utter falsehood '—I would I had thee in a desert with thy troop around thee; —and I, but with my sword in this unshackled hand!—

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: Is it to be credited that Rolla, the renown'd Peruvian hero—shou'd be detected like a spy, skulking through our camp?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Skulking!

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: But answer to the General—he is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: What do I see! Rolla!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: O! to thy surprise, no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: And bound too!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: So fast, thou need'st not fear approaching me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: The guards surpris'd him, passing our out∣post.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Release him instantly.—Believe me, I re∣gret this insult.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: You feel then as you ought.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Nor can I brook to see a warrior of Rolla's same disarm'd—accept this, tho' it has been thy enemy's. (Gives a sword.) The Spaniards know the courtesy that's due to valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: And the Peruvian, how to forget offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: May not Rolla and Pizarro cease to be fo?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: When the sea divides us; yes!—May I now depart?

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: And shall I not again be intercepted?

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: No!—let the word be given that Rolla passes freely.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DAVILLA and Soldiers, with the Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Here are two soldiers, captived yesterday, who have escap'd from the Peruvian hold,—and by the secret way we have so long endeavoured to discover.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Silence, imprudent! Seest thou not—?

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: In their way, they found a Peruvian child, who seems—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: What is the imp to me?—Bid them toss it into the sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Gracious heaven! it is Alonzo's child!—give it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Ha! Alonzo's child! Welcome, thou pretty hostage. Now Alonzo is again my pri∣soner!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Thou wilt not keep the infant from its mo∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Will I not! What, when I shall meet Alonzo in the heat of the victorious fight, think'st thou I shall not have a check upon the valour of his heart, when he is reminded that a word of mine is this child's death?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: I do not understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: My vengeance has a long arrear of hate to settle with Alonzo! and this pledge may help to settle the account.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Man! Man! Art thou a man? Could'st thou hurt that innocnt? By Heaven! its smiling in thy face.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Tell me, does it resemble Cora?

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Pizarro! thou hast set my heart on fire —If thou do'st harm that child, think not his blood will sink into the barren sand; No! faithful to the eager hope that now trembles in this indignant heart, 'twill rise to the common God of nature and humanity, and cry aloud for vengeance on its accursed destroyer's head.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Be that peril mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol
SP.P: Behold me at thy feet—Me, Rolla!—Me, the preserver of thy life—Me, that have never yet bent or bow'd be∣fore created man!—In humble agony I sue to you —prostrate I implore you—but spare that child, and I will be your slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Rolla! still art thou free to go—this boy remains with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Then was this sword Heaven's gift, not thine! Seizes the Child)—Who moves one step to follow me, dies upon the spot.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Pursue him instantly—but spare his life. [Exeunt Almagro and soldiers.] With what fury he defends himself!—Ha!—he fells them to the ground—and now—

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: Three of your brave soldiers are already victims to your command to spare this madman's life; and if he once gains the thicket—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Spare him no longer. [Exit Almagro.] Their guns must reach him—he'll yet escape—hollow to those horse—the Peruvian sees them —and now he turns among the rocks—then is his retreat cut off.

SP.SPEAKER: [Rolla
SP.P: crosses a wooden bridge over the cataract, pursued by the soldiers—they fire at him—a shot strikes him—Pizarro exclaims—
Piz. Now! quick! quick! seize the child!— [Rolla tears from the rock the tree which supports the bridge, and retreats by the back ground, bearing off the child.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: By Hell! he has escaped!—and with the child unhurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: No—he bears his death with him—Be∣lieve me, I saw him struck upon the side.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: But the child is sav'd—Alonzo's child! Oh! the furies of disappointed vengeance!

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: Away with the revenge of words—let us to deeds—Forget not we have acquired the knowledge of the secret pass, which thro' the rocky cavern's gloom brings you at once to the strong hold, where are lodged their women and their treasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Right, Almagro! Swift as thy thought draw forth a daring and a chosen band—I will not wait for numbers.—Stay, Almagro! Val∣verde is informed Elvira dies to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: He is—and one request alone she—

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: I'll hear of none.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: The boon is small—'tis but for the no∣viciate habit which you first beheld her in—she wishes not to suffer in the gaudy trappings, which remind her of her shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Well, do as thou wilt—but tell Valverde, that at our return, as his life shall answer it, to let me hear that she is dead.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter ATALIBA, followed by CORA and ALONZO.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Oh! avoid me not, Ataliba! To whom, but to her King, is the wretched mother to address her griefs?—The Gods refuse to hear my prayers! Did not my Alonzo fight for you?—and will not my sweet boy, if thou'lt but restore him to me, one day fight thy battles too?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Oh! my suffering love—my poor heart-broken Cora!—you but wound our Sovereign's feeling soul, and not relieve thy own.

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Is he our sovereign, and has he not the power to give me back my child?

SP.SPEAKER: Ata.
SP.P: When I reward desert, or can relieve my people, I feel what is the real glory of a King—when I hear them suffer, and cannot aid them, I mourn the impotence of all mortal power.
Rolla! Rolla! Rolla!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter ROLLA, bleeding with the child, follow'd by Peruvian soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: Thy child!
SP.STAGE: (Gives the child into Cora's arms, and falls.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cora.
SP.P: Oh God!—there's blood upon him!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: 'Tis my blood, Cora!

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Rolla, thou diest!

SP.SPEAKER: Rol.
SP.P: For thee, and Cora.—

SP.SPEAKER: Orano.
SP.P: Treachery has revealed our asylum in the rocks. Even now the foe assails the peaceful band retired for protection there.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Lose not a moment!—Swords be quick.

—Your wives and children cry to you—Bear our lov'd hero's body in the van—'Twill raise the fury of our men to madness.—Now, fell Pizarro! the death of one of us is near!—Away! Be the word of assault, Revenge and Rolla!—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: A romantic part of the Recess among the Rocks—(Alarms) Women are seen stying, pursued by the Spanish Soldiers.—The Peruvian soldiers drive the Spanirds back from the Field.—The Fight is con∣tinued on the Heights.
Enter PIZARRO, ALMAGRO, VALVERDE, and Spanish Soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ez.
SP.P:
Well!—if surrounded, we must perish in
the centre of them—Where do Rolla and Alonzo hide their heads?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Alonzo answers thee, and Alonzo's sword shall speak for Rolla.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Thou know'st the advantage of thy num∣bers. —Thou dar'st not singly face Pizarro.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Peruvians, stir not a man!—Be this con∣test only our's.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Spaniards!—observe ye the same.
They fight. Alonzo's shield is broken, and he is beat down.

SP.SPEAKER: Piz.
SP.P: Now, traitor, to thy heart!
At this moment Elvira enters, habited as when Pizarro first beheld her.—Pizarro, appalled, staggers back. Alonzo renews the Fight, and slays him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ata.
SP.P: My brave Alonzo!

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: Alonzo, we submit.—Spare us! we will embark, and leave the coast.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Elvira will confess I sav'd her life; she has sav'd thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Fear not. You are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Valverde speaks the truth;—nor could he think to meet me here.—An awful impulse which my soul could not resist, impell'd me hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Noble Elvira! my preserver! How can I speak what I, Aaliba, and his rescued country, owe to thee? If amid these grateful innocents thou woud'st remain—

SP.SPEAKER: Elv.
SP.P: Alonzo, no!—the destination of my future life is fix'd. Humbled in penitence, I will endea∣vour to atone the guilty errors, which, however mask'd by shallow cheerfulness, have long con∣sum'd my secret heart.—When, by my sufferings purified, and penitence sincere, my soul shall dare address the Throne of Mercy in behalf of others, —for thee, Alonzo; for thy Cora, and thy child; for thee, thou virtuous Monarch, and the inno∣cent race you reign over, shall Elvira's-prayers ad∣dress the God of Nature.—Valverde, you have preserved my life. Cherish humanity—avoid the foul examples thou hast view'd.—Spaniards return∣ing to your native home, assure your rulers, they mistake the road to glory, or to power.—Tell them, that the pursuits of avarice, conquest, and ambi∣tion, never yet made a people happy, or a nation great.—
SP.STAGE: (Casts a look of agony on the dead body of Pi∣zarro as she passes, and exit.)

DIV3.STAGE: Valverde, Almagra, and Spanish Soldiers, exeunt, bearing off Pizarro's Body.—On a signal from Alonzo, flourish of Music.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Ataliba! think not I wish to check the voice of triumph—when I entreat we first may pay the tribute to our lov'd Rolla's memory.

DIV3.STAGE: A solemn March—Procession of Peruvian Soldiers, bearing Rolla's Body on a Bier, surrounded by Mi∣litary Trophies. The Priests and Priestesses at∣tending chaunt a Dige over the Bier.—Alonzo and Cora kneel on either side of it, and kiss Rolla's hands in silent agony—In the looks of the King, and of all present, the Triumph of the Day is lost, in mourning for the fallen Hero.
